revision.text:
{{Infobox baseball biography |name=Thurman Munson |image=Munson 2.jpg |caption= |position=[[Catcher]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{birth date|1947|6|7}} |birth_place=[[Akron, Ohio]] |death_date={{death date and age|1979|8|2|1947|6|7}} |death_place=[[Green Township, Summit County, Ohio|Green Township, Ohio]] |debutleague = MLB |debutdate=August 8 |debutyear=1969 |debutteam=New York Yankees |finalleague = MLB |finaldate=August 1 |finalyear=1979 |finalteam=New York Yankees |statleague = MLB |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.292 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=113 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=701 |teams= *[[New York Yankees]] ({{mlby|1969}}–{{mlby|1979}}) |highlights= *7× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] ([[1971 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1971]], [[1973 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1973]]–[[1978 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1978]]) *2× [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1977}}, {{wsy|1978}}) *[[AL MVP]] (1976) *[[AL Rookie of the Year]] (1970) *3× [[Gold Glove Award]] (1973–1975) *[[List of New York Yankees team captains|New York Yankees captain]] (1976–1979) *[[New York Yankees#Retired numbers|New York Yankees No. 15]] retired * [[Monument Park (Yankee Stadium)|Monument Park]] honoree }} '''Thurman Lee Munson''' (June 7, 1947 – August 2, 1979) was an American professional [[baseball]] [[catcher]] who played 11 seasons in [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) for the [[New York Yankees]] (1969–1979). A seven-time [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]], Munson had a career [[batting average]] of .292 with 113 [[home runs]] and 701 [[run batted in|runs batted in]] (RBIs). Known for his outstanding fielding, he won the [[Rawlings Gold Glove Award|Gold Glove Award]] in three consecutive years (1973–75).
Born in [[Akron, Ohio]], Munson was selected as the fourth pick of the [[1968 Major League Baseball draft|1968 MLB draft]] and was named as the catcher on the [[1968 College Baseball All-America Team|1968 College Baseball All-American Team]]. Munson hit over .300 in his two seasons in the [[Minor league baseball|minor leagues]], establishing himself as a top prospect. He became the Yankees' starting catcher late in the [[1969 New York Yankees season|1969 season]], and after his first complete season in [[1970 New York Yankees season|1970]], in which he batted .302, he was voted [[American League]] (AL) [[Major League Baseball Rookie of the Year Award|Rookie of the Year]]. Considered the "heart and soul" of the Yankees, Munson was named [[List of New York Yankees team captains|captain of the Yankees]] in 1976, the team's first since [[Lou Gehrig]]. That same year, he won the AL [[MLB Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player (MVP) Award]], making him the only Yankee to win the Rookie of the Year and MVP Awards.
Munson led the Yankees to three consecutive [[World Series]] appearances from [[1976 World Series|1976]] to [[1978 World Series|1978]], winning championships in the latter two years. He is the first player in baseball history to be named a College Baseball All-American and then in MLB win a Rookie of the Year Award, MVP Award, Gold Glove Award, and World Series championship. He is also the only catcher in MLB postseason history to record at least a .300+ batting average (.357), 20 RBIs (22), and 20 defensive [[caught stealing]]s (24).
During an off day in the summer of [[1979 New York Yankees season|1979]], Munson died at age 32 while practicing landing his [[Cessna Citation]] aircraft at {{nowrap|[[Akron–Canton Airport]].}} He suffered a broken neck as result of the crash, and his cause of death was asphyxiation.<ref name=mdipc>{{cite news |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1979/08/03/page/73/article/munson-dies-in-plane-crash |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Munson dies in plane crash |date=August 3, 1979 |page=1, sec. 5}}</ref><ref name=tbysmkipc>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Cw0wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iAIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3091%2C2937686 |work=Toledo Blade |location=(Ohio)|agency=Associated Press |title=Yankees' star Munson is killed in plane crash |date=August 3, 1979 |page=1}}</ref><ref name=nlcloym>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7fdLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vu4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6923%2C1367178 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title='New love' claims life of Yanks' Munson |date=August 3, 1979 |page=33}}</ref> The Yankees honored him by immediately [[New York Yankees#Retired numbers|retiring]] his {{nowrap|uniform 15,<ref name=yofimt>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4epIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xIIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3645%2C993234 |work=Youngstown Vindicator |location=(Ohio) |agency=Associated Press |title=Yankees, O's, fans in Munson tribute |last=Bock |first=Hal |date=August 4, 1979 |page=13}}</ref>}} and dedicating a plaque to him in [[Monument Park (Yankee Stadium)|Monument Park]].
==Amateur career== Munson was born in [[Akron, Ohio]] to Darrell Vernon Munson and Ruth Myrna Smylie, the youngest of four children.<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=12}}</ref> His father was a [[World War II]] veteran who became a [[truck driver]] while his mother was a homemaker.<ref name="Appel_15">{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=15}}</ref> When he turned eight, the Munson family moved to nearby [[Canton, Ohio|Canton]].<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=13}}</ref> He was taught how to play baseball by his older brother Duane, and usually played baseball with kids Duane's age, who were four years older.<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=16}}</ref> His brother left to join the [[United States Air Force]] while Thurman was a freshman in high school.<ref name="Appel_15"/>
Munson attended [[Lehman High School (Canton, Ohio)|Lehman High School]], where he was captain of the [[High school football|football]], [[basketball]], and baseball teams and was all-city and -state in all three sports.<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=26}}</ref> He played [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] in football, [[Guard (basketball)|guard]] in basketball, and mostly [[shortstop]] in baseball.<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=27}}</ref> Munson switched to catcher in his senior year in order to handle the pitching prowess of his teammate, Jerome Pruett (a fifth-round draft pick of the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in 1965 who never reached the majors).<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|p=29}}</ref> He attracted scholarship offers from various colleges, and opted to attend nearby [[Kent State Golden Flashes|Kent State University]] on scholarship, where he was a teammate of [[pitcher]] and [[Sports commentator|broadcaster]] [[Steve Stone (baseball)|Steve Stone]].
In the summer of {{baseball year|1967}}, Munson joined the [[Cape Cod Baseball League]], where he led the [[Chatham A's]] to their first league title with a prodigious .420 [[batting average]]. In recognition of this achievement and his subsequent professional achievements, the ''Thurman Munson Batting Award'' is given each season to the league's {{nowrap|batting champion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capecodbaseball.org/archives/Records/awards_batting.htm|title=Cape Cod Baseball League Thurman Munson Award Winners|accessdate=2009-11-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120223135/http://capecodbaseball.org/archives/Records/awards_batting.htm|archivedate=2010-11-20|df=}}</ref>}}
==Professional career== ===1968–1970=== Munson was selected by the Yankees with the fourth overall pick in the [[1968 Major League Baseball draft]]. In his only full minor league season, he batted .301 with six [[home run]]s and 37 [[runs batted in]] for the [[Binghamton Triplets]] in their final season ({{baseball year|1968}}), and made his first appearance in [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] in August 1968, when the Triplets came to play an [[exhibition game]] against the Yankees.<ref>{{harvp|Appel|2009|pp=7–8}}</ref> He was batting .363 for the [[Syracuse Chiefs]] in {{baseball year|1969}} when he earned a promotion to the New York Yankees.
Munson made his major league debut on August 8, 1969, in the second game of a [[Doubleheader (baseball)|doubleheader]] against the [[Oakland Athletics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYA/NYA196908082.shtml|title=New York Yankees 5, Oakland A's 0|date=1969-08-08|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref> Munson went two for three with a [[walk (baseball)|walk]], one RBI and two [[runs scored]]. Two days later, his first major league home run was the second of three consecutive home runs hit by the Yankees off [[Lew Krausse, Jr.|Lew Krausse]] in a 5-1 Yankee victory over the A's.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYA/NYA196908100.shtml|title=New York Yankees 5, Oakland A's 1|date=1969-08-10|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref> For the season, Munson batted .256 with one home run and nine RBI. He made 97 plate appearances, but drew ten walks and had one [[sacrifice fly]], which gave him 86 official at bats, and allowed him to go into the {{baseball year|1970}} season still technically a rookie.
The Yankees used the pair of [[Jake Gibbs]] and [[Frank Fernández (baseball)|Frank Fernández]] at catcher for most of 1969. During the off season, the Yankees dealt Fernández to the A's. Munson responded by batting .302 with seven home runs and 57 RBI, and making 80 assists en route to receiving the 1970 [[American League]] Rookie of the Year award.
===1971–1974=== Munson received his first of seven All-Star nods in {{baseball year|1971}}, catching the last two innings without an at-bat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ALS/ALS197107130.shtml|title=1971 All-Star Game|date=1971-07-13|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref> An outstanding fielder, Munson committed only one [[error (baseball)|error]] all season. It occurred on June 18 against the [[Baltimore Orioles]] when opposing catcher [[Andy Etchebarren]] knocked Munson unconscious on a play at the plate, dislodging the ball.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BAL/BAL197106180.shtml|title=Baltimore Orioles 6, New York Yankees 4|date=1971-06-18|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref> He also only allowed nine passed balls all season and caught 36 of a potential 59 [[Stolen base|base stealers]] for a 61% caught stealing percentage.
Munson was known for his longstanding feud with [[Boston Red Sox]] counterpart [[Carlton Fisk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedeadballera.com/MunsonFisk.html|title=The Munson/Fisk Rivalry|accessdate=2009-11-25}}</ref> One particular incident that typified their feud, and the [[Yankees – Red Sox rivalry]] in general, occurred on August 1, {{baseball year|1973}} at [[Fenway Park]]. With the score tied at 2–2 in the top of the ninth and runners on first and third, Munson attempted to score from third on [[Gene Michael]]'s missed bunt attempt.
As Red Sox pitcher [[John Curtis (baseball)|John Curtis]] let his first pitch go, Munson broke for the plate. Michael tried to bunt, and missed. With Munson coming, Fisk elbowed the Yankee shortstop out of the way and braced for Munson, who barreled into Fisk. Fisk held onto the ball, but Munson remained tangled with Fisk as [[Felipe Alou]], who was on first, attempted to advance. The confrontation at the plate triggered a ten-minute [[bench-clearing brawl]] in which both catchers were ejected.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BOS/BOS197308010.shtml|title=Boston Red Sox 3, New York Yankees 2|date=1973-08-01|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref>
Munson made his second All-Star team and won his first of three straight [[Gold Glove Award]]s in 1973. He also emerged as more of a slugger for the Yankees, batting .300 for the first time since 1970, and hitting a career high twenty home runs. In {{baseball year|1974}}, Munson was elected to start his first of three consecutive All-Star games, going one for three with a walk and a run scored.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NLS/NLS197407230.shtml|title=1974 All-Star Game|date=1974-07-23|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref>
===1975–1976=== Munson batted a career high .318 in {{baseball year|1975}}, which was third in the league behind [[Rod Carew]] and [[Fred Lynn]]. For the start of the {{baseball year|1976}} season, Munson was named the first [[List of New York Yankees team captains|Yankees team captain]] since [[Lou Gehrig]] retired in {{baseball year|1939}}. He responded by batting .302 with 17 home runs and 105 RBI to receive the American League MVP Award and lead the Yankees to their first [[World Series]] appearance since {{wsy|1964}}. He batted .435 with three RBI and three runs scored in the [[1976 American League Championship Series|American League Championship Series]] against the [[1976 Kansas City Royals season|Kansas City Royals]], and batted .529 with two RBI and two runs scored in the [[1976 World Series|World Series]] against the [[1976 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]]. Already down three games to none, Munson went four for four in the final game of the Series at [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]], but New York was swept by the "[[Big Red Machine]]." Combined with the hits he got in his final two at bats in game three, his six consecutive hits tied a World Series record set by [[Goose Goslin]] of the [[1924 Washington Senators season|Washington Senators]] in {{wsy|1924}}.
Reds catcher [[Johnny Bench]] was named the World Series MVP in 1976. A fairly obvious comparison of opposing backstops was made to Reds [[Manager (baseball)|manager]] [[Sparky Anderson]] during the post-World Series [[press conference]], to which, Anderson responded, "Munson is an outstanding ballplayer and he would hit .300 in the [[National League]], but you don't ever compare anybody to Johnny Bench. Don't never embarrass nobody by comparing them to Johnny Bench." Munson was visibly upset by these comments when he got on the mic shortly afterwards.<ref>''All Roads Lead to October'' (chapter 10) by Maury Allen, St. Martin's Press 2000 {{ISBN|0-312-26175-6}}</ref>
===1977–1979=== Munson batted .308 with 100 RBI in [[1977 New York Yankees season|1977]], giving him three consecutive seasons batting .300 or better with 100 or more RBI each year. He was the first catcher to accomplish the feat in three consecutive years since Yankee [[MLB Hall of Fame|Hall of Famer]] [[Bill Dickey]]'s four straight seasons from {{baseball year|1936}}-1939, matched only by [[Mike Piazza]] since ({{baseball year|1996}}–{{baseball year|1998}}). The Yankees repeated as [[1977 American League Championship Series|American League Champions]], and faced the [[1977 Los Angeles Dodgers season|Los Angeles Dodgers]] in the [[1977 World Series|World Series]]. Munson batted .320 with a home run and three RBI in the Yankees four games to two victory over the Dodgers. The Dodgers had stolen 114 bases during the regular season, yet Munson caught four of six potential base stealers in the first four games of the series to keep the speedy Dodgers grounded in the final two.
In [[1978 New York Yankees season|1978]], the Yankees and [[1978 Kansas City Royals season|Royals]] faced each other for the third consecutive time in the [[1978 American League Championship Series|ALCS]]. Tied at a game apiece, and trailing {{nowrap|5–4}} in the bottom of the eighth inning of game three, Munson hit the longest home run of his career, a{{convert|475|ft|adj=on}} shot off [[Doug Bird]] over Yankee Stadium's Monument Park in left-center field, to give the Yankees a {{nowrap|6–5 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYA/NYA197810060.shtml|title=1978 American League Championship Series Game Three|date=1978-10-06|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref>}} They won the pennant the next day, and went on to beat the [[1978 Los Angeles Dodgers season|Dodgers]] again in the [[1978 World Series|World Series]] in six games, winning the final four. Munson batted .320 (8-for-25) with 7 RBI's in this Series and also caught [[Ron Cey]]'s foul pop-up for the final out.
Munson's World Series championships in 1977 and 1978 made him only the second catcher in baseball history, at the time, to win a Rookie of the Year Award, an MVP Award, a Gold Glove Award, and a World Series title during his career. Johnny Bench had become the first catcher to win all four of these awards when he won his own World Series titles with the Reds in 1975 and 1976. Subsequently, and more recently, when Buster Posey won his first Gold Glove Award in 2016 he also joined this list of three catchers in all of baseball history to win all four awards. But as a further point on unique contributions to the game, since Posey and Munson both were named as College Baseball All-Americans based upon their collegiate baseball careers, they now share the additional distinction of being the only two Catchers in history named to an All-American Team who also own a ROY, MVP, GG, and World Series Title.
The Yankees had lost three in a row, and were in fourth place, eleven games behind the [[1979 Baltimore Orioles season|Baltimore Orioles]] in the [[American League East]] heading into the All-Star break in [[1979 New York Yankees season|1979]]. Despite a .288 average, the wear-and-tear of catching was beginning to take its toll on Munson, and he was overlooked for the [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|American League All-Star team]]. Frequently homesick, he had a well-known desire to play for the [[Cleveland Indians]] in order to be closer to his family in Canton,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/yankees/index.ssf/2009/08/catcher_thurman_munson_the_cap.html|title=Catcher Thurman Munson, The Captain, was heart and soul of the NY Yankees|date=2009-08-01}}</ref> and was also considering retiring at the end of the season. At the end of July, the Yankees were still in fourth place at {{winning percentage|57|48|record=y}}, fourteen games behind {{nowrap|Baltimore.<ref name=yvmjloop>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3upIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xIIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2939%2C180514 |work=Youngstown Vindicator |location=(Ohio) |title=Major loop standings |date=August 1, 1979 |page=33}}</ref>}}
==Death== [[File:MartinHunterGulden1979.jpg|300px|right|thumb|[[Brad Gulden]] (with [[Billy Martin]] and [[Catfish Hunter]]) was one of two catchers to play in the game after Thurman Munson's funeral. His black memorial armband is visible.]] Munson had been flying for over a year and purchased a [[Cessna Citation I|Cessna Citation I/SP]] jet so he could fly home to his family in Canton on off-days.<ref name=mrspapfst>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Dg0wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iAIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6912%2C4393970 |work=Toledo Blade |location=(Ohio)|last=Lauck |first=Dan|title=Munson relative says plane a problem from start|date=August 6, 1979 |page=16}}</ref> On the afternoon of Thursday, August 2, 1979, he was practicing takeoffs and landings at the {{nowrap|[[Akron-Canton Regional Airport]]}} with friend Jerry Anderson and flight instructor Dave Hall.<ref name=mdipc/><ref name=tbysmkipc/><ref name="DN01">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/yankees/2009/08/02/2009-08-02_the_mourning_after_munsons_death.html|title=Jerry Narron recalls night he replaced Thurman Munson for Yankees|last=Brennan|first=Sean|date=2009-08-01|publisher=New York Daily News}}</ref> Shortly after {{nowrap|3:40 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]],}} Munson had received clearance for takeoff and three [[Touch-and-go landing|touch-and-go landings]] on runway 23, which were {{nowrap|completed.<ref name=ntsbapr80/>}}
While on approach for the fourth and final landing on a different runway (19), Munson did not extend the flaps and allowed the aircraft to sink too low before increasing engine power, causing the jet to clip a tree and fall short of the runway. The plane then hit a tree stump and burst into flames,<ref>''All Roads Lead to October'' (chapter 10) by Maury Allen, St. Martin's Press 2000 {{ISBN|0-312-26175-6}}, reprinted at {{cite web |url=http://www.thurmanmunson.com/history.html |title=last entry for the ThurmanMunson.com history page |accessdate=2007-02-02 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202205405/http://www.thurmanmunson.com/history.html |archivedate=February 2, 2007 |df= }}</ref> on Greensburg Road, {{convert|870|ft|round=5}} short of runway 19.<ref name=ntsbapr80>{{cite web |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/AAR8002.pdf |publisher=National Transportation Safety Board |agency=(Aircraft Accident Report) |title=Thurman L Munson, Cessna Citation, 501 N15NY, August 2, 1979 |date=April 16, 1980}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/news_archives/video-vault-1979-akron-canton-airport-plane-crash-killed-thurman-munson|title=Video Vault: 1979 Akron-Canton Airport plane crash killed Thurman Munson|first=Tom Livingston,|last=newsnet5.com|date=2 August 2012|publisher=}}</ref><ref name=tfyltrnydn>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/yankees/thurman-munson-final-hours-article-1.394320 |work=New York Daily News |last=Coffey |first=Wayne |title=25 years later, Thurman Munson's last words remain a symbol of his life |agency=(originally from 2004)|date=August 1, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
Hall and Anderson both survived the accident. Hall received burns on his arms and hands, and Anderson received burns on his face, arm and neck. Munson suffered a broken neck and would have most likely suffered from [[quadriplegia]] had he lived. Munson died of [[asphyxiation]] due to the inhalation of superheated air and toxic {{nowrap|substances.<ref name=ntsbapr80/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=md4iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=48sFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3234,3052035&dq=thurman+munson+cause+of+death&hl=en |title=Coroner: Paralyzed Munson couldn't escape|publisher=}}</ref>}}
The [[National Transportation Safety Board]] (NTSB) investigation into the crash stated that the probable cause was "...the pilot's failure to recognize the need for, and to take action to maintain, sufficient airspeed to prevent a stall into the ground during an attempted landing. The pilot also failed to recognize the need for timely and sufficient power application to prevent the stall during an approach conducted inadvertently without flaps extended. Contributing to the pilot's inability to recognize the problem and to take proper action was his failure to use the appropriate checklist and his nonstandard pattern procedures which resulted in an abnormal approach profile." Munson was not wearing the available shoulder harness restraint, only a lap belt, which contributed to the severity of his injuries.<ref name=ntsbapr80/>
==Legacy== {{MLBBioRet |Image =ThurmanMunson15.jpg |Name =Thurman Munson |Number =15 |Team =New York Yankees |Year =1979 |}} The day after his death, before the start of the Yankees' four-game set with the [[1979 Baltimore Orioles season|Baltimore Orioles]] in the [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Bronx]], the team paid tribute to their deceased captain in a pre-game ceremony in which the starters stood at their defensive positions, save for the catcher's box, which remained empty. Following a prayer by Cardinal [[Terence Cooke]], a moment of silence and "[[America The Beautiful|America the Beautiful]]" by [[Robert Merrill]], the fans (announced attendance 51,151) burst into an eight-minute standing ovation.<ref name=yofimt/> Catcher [[Jerry Narron]], who replaced Munson behind the plate that night,<ref name="DN01" /> remained in the [[dugout (baseball)|dugout]] and did not enter the field until stadium announcer [[Bob Sheppard]] said, "And now it is time to play ball. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your co-operation."
On August 6, the entire Yankee team attended Munson's funeral in Canton. Teammates [[Lou Piniella]] and [[Bobby Murcer]], who were Munson's best friends, gave eulogies at the gathering of 700 at the [[Canton Memorial Civic Center]].<ref name=mnsneulg>{{cite news |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1979/08/07/page/39/article/munson-eulogized-by-yankee-teammates |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Munson eulogized by Yankee teammates |date=August 7, 1979 |page=1, sec.4}}</ref><ref name=msahaf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8fdLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vu4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6533%2C4114127 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Munson's son a hit at funeral |date=August 7, 1979 |page=19}}</ref> That night before a national viewing audience on [[Major League Baseball on ABC|ABC]]'s ''[[Monday Night Baseball]]'', the Yankees beat the Orioles 5-4 in New York, with Murcer driving in all five runs with a three-run home run in the seventh inning and a two-run single in the bottom of the ninth.<ref name=cteul>{{cite news |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1979/08/07/page/39/article/murcer-delivers-a-tribute|work=Chicago Tribune |title=Murcer delivers a tribute |date=August 7, 1979 |page=1, sec.4}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYA/NYA197908060.shtml|title=New York Yankees 5, Baltimore Orioles 5|date=1979-08-06|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com}}</ref>
Yankee owner [[George Steinbrenner]] [[List of Major League Baseball retired numbers|retired]] Munson's number 15 immediately upon his catcher's death.<ref name=yofimt/> On September 20, {{baseball year|1980}}, a plaque dedicated to Munson's memory was placed in [[Monument Park (Yankee Stadium)|Monument Park]]. The plaque bears excerpts from an inscription composed by Steinbrenner and flashed on the stadium scoreboard the day after his death: {{quote|Our captain and leader has not left us, today, tomorrow, this year, next ... Our endeavors will reflect our love and admiration for him.}}
[[File:Munson Locker.JPG|thumb|Munson's locker in the [[New York Yankees Museum]], 2009.]]The locker that Munson used, along with a bronzed set of his catching equipment, was donated to the [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]. Despite a packed clubhouse, Munson's final locker position was never reassigned. The empty locker next to Yankee team captain [[Derek Jeter]]'s, with Munson's number 15 on it, remained as a tribute to the Yankees' lost catcher in the original Yankee Stadium until the Stadium closed in 2008. Munson's locker was moved in one piece to the New [[Yankee Stadium]]. It is located in the New York Yankees Museum. Visitors can view the Yankees Museum on game days from when the gates open to the end of the eighth inning and during Yankee Stadium tours. Munson's number 15 is also displayed on the center-field wall at [[Thurman Munson Stadium]], a minor-league ballpark in Canton. Munson is buried at Canton's Sunset Hills Burial Park.
A modest, one-block street at Concourse Village East and 156th Street in [[The Bronx]] was named Thurman Munson Way in 1979. Two school buildings, which house several schools including Henry [[Lou Gehrig]] Junior High School, have since been built on the street.<ref name="paltry tribute">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/nyregion/18yankees.html?hpw "Paltry Tribute to a Yankee Lost Too Soon"] by Sam Dolnick, ''The New York Times'', April 16, 2010 (p. CT1 April 18, 2010 NY ed.). Retrieved 2010-04-17.</ref>
On August 1, {{baseball year|1980}}, the day before the first anniversary of the accident, the Yankees filed a $4.5-million lawsuit against Cessna Aircraft Co. and Flight Safety International, Inc. (the company who was training Munson to fly), with team spokesman John J. McCarty saying "we asked for $4.5 million because that is what Munson would be worth if the Yankees traded him." Munson's widow, Diana, also filed a $42.2 million wrongful death lawsuit against the two companies. Cessna offered Munson a special deal on flying lessons if he would take them from [[FlightSafety International]]. Rather than requiring Munson to take a two-week safety class in [[Kansas]], FlightSafety assigned a "traveling instructor" to go on the road with him, and train him between ballgames.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/02/nyregion/follow-up-on-the-news-munson-case.html|title=Follow-Up on the News; Munson Case|date=1982-05-02|work=The New York Times | first=Richard | last=Haitch | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref> The suit was eventually settled out of court.
==Family== In September 1968, Munson married Diana Dominick at [[Basilica of Saint John the Baptist (Canton, Ohio)|St. John's Church]] in Canton. He is survived by Diana<ref>{{YouTube|LkyYzWq3i04|"Diana Munson & Goose Gossage at Modell's Grand Central"}} by Katherine Hart, YouTube network video interview, August 06, 2008. News outlets sometimes spell the name Diane, including the ''NYTimes''; however, since "Diana" is used in a recorded face-to-face video interview situation here, the editor has brought all references to that spelling. Retrieved 2010-04-19.</ref> and their three children: daughter Tracy, daughter Kelly and son Michael. Diana Munson threw out the ceremonial first pitch at Game 3 of the [[1997 World Series]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio]].
==Baseball accomplishments== Munson had a career .357 batting average in the postseason with three home runs, 22 RBI and 19 runs scored. His batting average in the World Series was .373. Munson threw out 44.48% of [[Baserunning|base runners]] who tried stealing a base on him, ranking him 11th on the all-time list.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/100BestCSCar.pdf 100 Best Catcher CS% Totals] at ''The Encyclopedia of Baseball Catchers''</ref> * 1st all time – Singles in World Series, 9 * 10th all time – Batting average by catcher, .292 * 11th all time – Postseason batting average, .357 * 11th all time – Caught stealing percentage * 16th all time – On base percentage by catcher * 20th all time – OPS by catcher * 24th all time – Slugging by catcher * 26th all time – Hits by catcher * 26th all time – Runs by catcher * AL Rookie of the Year (1970) * AL MVP (1976) * 3× Gold Glove Award * 3 AL Pennants * 2 World Series titles * 7× All Star

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Yonassan Gershom |image = Rabbi Yonassan Gershom 2008.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1947 |birth_place = [[Berkeley, California]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Sandstone, Minnesota]] |nationality = American {{flagicon|US}} |other_names = |known_for = [[Reincarnation research]] |education = [[Minnesota State University, Mankato]] |employer = |occupation = [[Rabbi]] and writer |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |spouse = [[Caryl Gershom]] |partner = |children = |parents = |relatives = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Yonassan Gershom''' is a [[Rabbi]] and writer who was ordained in the [[Jewish Renewal]] movement during the 1980s and is now a follower of [[Breslov (Hasidic dynasty)|Breslov]] [[Hasidism]]. He was associated with the early days of the [[B'nai Or]] movement, a forerunner of Jewish Renewal, in which he was ordained by Rabbi [[Zalman Schachter-Shalomi]] in 1986,<ref>Gelfman, Patti Simon, "Judaism in a New Age," ''Minnesota Jewish Life,'' January 1988</ref> although he is not in agreement with the direction that the movement has taken in more recent years<ref>Gershom, ''49 Gates of Light,'' 4th edition, Lulu Press 2009, pp. 102–108</ref>
Gershom lives on a farm in rural Minnesota, where he writes and conducts himself as a "cyber-rabbi" on the Internet.<ref>Hanson, Linda, "Tending his Flocks: Sandstone Rabbi Cares for his animals at home while taking his ministry to the Internet," ''Duluth News Tribune,'' October 14, 2000, pg.4C</ref> In 1997 he made a pilgrimage to the grave of Rabbi [[Nachman of Breslov]] in [[Uman]], [[Ukraine]], a trip that has strongly influenced his later writings. Until this point, "he wasn't aware how much the rural experience shaped Hasidism. It gave him a deeper understanding of Hasidic stories and the Torah."<ref>Hanson, pg.4C</ref> He has served on the Advisory Board of the [[Jewish Vegetarians of North America]] (JVNA) and is active in the vegetarian and [[animal welfare]] movements.<ref>Schwartz, Richard H.,''Judaism and Vegetarianism,'' 3rd edition, Lantern Books, New York. 2001. pp.124–125</ref> In 2013 he was widely quoted as opposing the use of live chickens for [[Kapparot]] ceremonies.<ref>cf. Rodman, Edmund J. "Atonement Chickens – Swung and Tossed", Jewish Journal of Los Angeles, September 3, 2013 and "Activists Will Rally in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Protest Chickens in Kaporos Rituals," News release from the [[Alliance to End Chickens as Kaporos]], September 4, 2013</ref>
Gershom is best known for having written several books on the topic of the [[Holocaust]] and [[reincarnation]]. ''Beyond the Ashes'' and ''From Ashes to Healing'' recount stories of people who claim to have died in the Holocaust and are now reincarnated,<ref>Lerner, Maura, "Stories of reincarnated victims of Holocaust led Rabbi on spiritual quest," ''Minneapolis Star Tribune,'' November 26, 1996</ref> while ''Jewish Tales of Reincarnation'' deals with Jewish accounts of reincarnation, including a few from the Holocaust but mostly others from classical Jewish texts and [[oral tradition]].
In his books on reincarnation, he discusses theories concerning whether Jews who died in the Holocaust did so as punishment for their sins in their previous lives. He argues that in the Jewish conception of evil and reincarnation (as opposed to the conception found in some other religions), suffering in this life is not necessarily punishment for wrongdoing in a previous life. Rather, he argues, undeserved suffering in this life can be purely due to the wrongdoing of the perpetrators and not some punishment for the victims.<ref>MacKenzie, Vicki, ''Reborn in the West: The Reincarnation Masters,'' Marlowe & Company, New York. pp. 107–109</ref> He does, however, argue that, according to the Jewish concept, wickedness can be accumulated over a succession of reincarnations. Thus, he argues, it is possible that the Nazis committed the Holocaust due to the evil they had accumulated through many lifetimes of persecuting and killing Jews throughout the preceding centuries. He cites that [[Adolf Hitler]] might have been a reincarnation of the biblical [[Amalek]].<ref>Steiger, Brad, ''Returning From the Light,'' Signet, New York. 1996. pp. 215–217</ref>
Gershom has appeared on several TV programs in connection with his reincarnation work, including [[Sightings (TV series)|Sightings]]<ref>''Sightings,'' "Hands of Remembrance," airdate 10/18/96</ref> and [[Unexplained Mysteries]]. The Duluth, Minnesota [[PBS]] station, WDSE, also featured him on their ''Venture North'' news magazine show in connection with his philosophy on gardening and Jewish spirituality.<ref>''Venture North,'' "The Rabbi's Garden," airdate October 19, 2000</ref> He appears in the 2007 documentary film, ''[[A Sacred Duty (film)|A Sacred Duty]]: Applying Jewish Values to Help Heal the World'', directed by [[Lionel Friedberg]] for the [[Jewish Vegetarians of North America]] (JVNA).
Although he is best known for his books on reincarnation, Gershom is also a lifelong [[pacifist]] and peace activist, who has written many articles on Judaism and [[nonviolence]], later collected into an anthology entitled ''Eight Candles of Consciousness.'' He was active in the peace movement in [[Minneapolis]] during the 1980s, and publicly protested against the policies of [[Meir Kahane]].<ref>cf. "Cuts off Payos to Protest Kahane," ''American Jewish World,'' May 26, 1985 and "The Payos Cutting – one Year Later," ''American Jewish World, January 30, 1986</ref> He is also a supporter of gay rights, basing his stance on equal rights under the law rather than theology.<ref>"Jews, Queers, and Closets," ''Equal Time,'' January 1993</ref> He graduated from [[Mankato State University]] in 1975 with a Bachelor of Science degree in German language and Native American Studies.
==Publications== '''On reincarnation:'''
*''Beyond the Ashes: Cases of Reincarnation from the Holocaust,'' A.R.E. Press, 1992. ({{ISBN|0876042930}}) *''From Ashes to Healing: Mystical Encounters with the Holocaust,'' A.R.E. Press, 1996. ({{ISBN|0876043406}}) *''Jewish Tales of Reincarnation,'' Jason Aronson, Inc., 2000. ({{ISBN|0765760835}}) *''Are Holocaust Victims Returning?" [[ebook]] anthology of articles on reincarnation reprinted from various periodicals, 2007.
'''On other topics'''
*''49 Gates of Light: Kabbalistic Meditations for Counting the Omer,'' Crown Point Enterprises, Minneapolis, 1987, reprinted as ''49 Gates of Light: a course in kabbalah,'' Lulu Press, Inc. 2010. *"Shamanism in the Jewish Tradition," included in Nicholson, Shirley (ed.), ''Shamanism: An Expanded View of Reality,'' Quest Books, Wheaton, Illinois, 1996. *"The Peace Stone" included in ''Seeing the Light: Personal Encounters with the Middle East and Islam,'' Curtis, Richard H. and McMahon, Janet (eds.), American Educational Trust, Washington DC, 1997. *''Eight Candles of Consciousness: Essays on Jewish Nonviolence,'' Lulu Press, Inc. Raleigh, NC, 2009. ({{ISBN|978-0-557-04922-6}}) *''Jewish Themes in Star Trek,'' Lulu Press, Inc. Raleigh, NC, 2009. ({{ISBN|978-0-557-04800-7}}) * Two dialogues with him on [[animal rights]] issues in Judaism ("Raising Holy Sparks: Hasidic Thought and Vegetarianism" and "A Dialogue on Nature Deficit Disorder") are included in ''[https://archive.org/details/WhoStoleMyReligion Who Stole My Religion?: Revitalizing Judaism and Applying Jewish Values to Help Heal our Imperiled Planet]'' by [[Richard H. Schwartz]], Lulu Press, Inc. Raleigh, NC, 2011. ({{ISBN|978-1-105-33646-1}}) *''Kapporos Then and Now: Toward a More Compassionate Tradition,'' Lulu Press, Inc., 2015. ({{ISBN|978-1-329-18940-9}}) *"Spock and Jews in the 1960s," included in ''Spockology:Essays on Spock and Leonard Nimoy from The Undiscovered Country Project and Friends,'' Neece, Kvin C. (editor), Createspace, 2015. ({{ISBN|978-1506108179}}) *"Rabbi Birds and Rooster Chicks: how I Became a Vegetarian," included in Yanklowitz, Schmuly, ''The Jewish Vegan,'' Shamyim v'Aretz Institute, 2015. ({{ISBN|978-1517393021}})
==See also== * [[Jewish vegetarianism]]
